properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong winds expected tonight. Southwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h are expected to develop late this evening along the Lake Ontario shoreline. Winds will veer into the west and diminish early Sunday morning. A wind warning may be issued later today as required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T00:14:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T08:15:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2968045176.2020
Area: Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected on Sunday. Total snowfall: close to 15 cm. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: overnight tonight into Sunday night. Remarks: Snow will develop overnight tonight in the west and spread eastwards. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are currently forecast, but there is the possibility some areas may reach warning criteria of 15 or more cm. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T00:11:52-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills continues. Bitterly cold arctic air will continue to remain entrenched over the Peace District. Occasional winds to 15 km/h will give wind chill values near minus 40 tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-18T23:03:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T07:04:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3153924888.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Up to 15 cm of snow expected today. Snow is expected to begin early this morning and then quickly become heavy today as a strong low pressure system approaches. Total snowfall accumulations near 15 cm can be expected by the time the snow tapers to flurries tonight. Southeasterly winds this morning and then northerly winds tonight gusting up to 50 km/h will also create areas of blowing snow giving reduced visibilities at times. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T02:06:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T10:07:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3676618612.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall today and tonight. Snow is forecast to begin this morning as a strong low pressure system approaches. The snow will then become heavy this afternoon into this evening. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm can be expected by the time the snow tapers to flurries Sunday morning. Local blowing and drifting snow can also be expected over open areas this afternoon and this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T02:11:51-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 15 cm of heavy snow today. Snow, heavy at times will continue into this afternoon, with total amounts near 15 cm expected across Southwestern Ontario. Strong southeasterly winds will whip up the freshly fallen snow causing very low visibility at times in blowing snow mostly this morning. The snow will taper off to a mixture of showers and wet flurries this afternoon south of a Grand Bend to St. Marys line. North of this line the snow may turn over briefly to a mix of wet flurries and showers early this evening. As cold arctic air returns again by Sunday, snow squalls in a brisk northwesterly flow off of Lake Huron are expected to affect the region starting Sunday morning. Snow squall watches may be issued as this event draws closer. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T00:42:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T08:43:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3563036711.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong southwesterly winds gusting to near 100 km/h will develop suddenly early this evening as a sharp cold front blasts through. Winds will diminish and veer into the west overnight. Isolated power outages are possible ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T01:50:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T09:51:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4250795727.2020

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Snow, briefly heavy at times, will accumulate to 5 to 10 centimetres by early this afternoon, then switch over fairly quickly to showers mixed at times with wet flurries this afternoon. Poor winter driving conditions from low visibility in occasional heavy snow and local blowing snow are expected into this afternoon. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. This winter weather travel advisory replaces the snowfall warning which was previously in effect, as total snowfall amounts are no longer expected to reach the warning threshold of 15 cm in a 12 hour period. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T00:59:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T09:49:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3757765219.2020
Area: Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous blizzard conditions continue, with very strong winds and visibility near zero in heavy snow and blowing snow. Locations: Avalon Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, and Bonavista Peninsula. Additional snowfall: 2 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h, except 130 along parts of the coast. Time span: until this afternoon. Remarks: Conditions are expected to improve this morning for most areas as the snow tapers off. But strong winds and blowing snow will persist over coastal areas exposed to the north into this afternoon. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-18T22:59:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T08:39:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0686331267.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 15 to 25 cm of heavy snow on tap today into this evening. Snow, heavy at times, will move over the region this morning. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected by this evening. Strong southeasterly winds gusting to 70 km/h will whip up freshly fallen snow today resulting in occasional very low to nil visibility in blowing snow today. The snow may change over to a mix of rain and wet snow for a few hours beginning this evening, as temperatures edge above the zero degree mark. Precipitation will then taper off to scattered flurries by Sunday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T01:59:35-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow will continue into Saturday with snowfall totals of 5 to 10 cm expected by Saturday evening. Higher amounts are expected over the Red River valley and southeastern Manitoba where warnings are currently in place. Northwesterly winds up to 50 gusting 70 km/h will spread eastwards across southern Manitoba on Saturday night, combining with the falling snow to produce areas of reduced visibility in blowing snow which will persist through Saturday with improvement occurring Saturday night. Warnings are in place for numerous regions in southern Manitoba. Please stay alert for updated bulletins. Anyone who has plans to travel on area highways tonight or Saturday should ensure that they check local weather forecasts (https://weather.gc.ca/forecast/canada/index_e.html?id=mb) regional highway conditions (https://manitoba511.ca/en/) before travelling. Ensure that your vehicle contains a winter emergency kit (https://www.getprepared.gc.ca/cnt/rsrcs/sfttps/tp201012-en.aspx) in case poor travelling conditions cause you to be stranded for a period of time. Poor travelling conditions have also developed through the Dakotas and Minnesota, where this system is bringing higher snowfall accumulations along with strong winds. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T00:38:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T08:39:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1868922563.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow over the weekend... A low pressure system will track across Southern Quebec and is expected to give 10 to 15 centimetres of snow between Saturday afternoon and Sunday afternoon. In addition, moderate to occasionally strong easterlies will cause blowing snow locally, mainly in exposed areas near the St Lawrence and Ottawa valleys. The snowfall, reduced visibilities and cold temperatures should make for poor road conditions and difficult travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected on Sunday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly winds of 70 km/h. Locations: Nova Scotia. Time span: Sunday morning to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin overnight into Sunday morning in the southwest and spread towards Cape Breton by noon. There may be a transition over to rain for parts of the Atlantic coast, but there remains some uncertainty on where or if the transition to rain will occur. Snowfall amounts may reach 15 cm. Blowing snow over exposed areas is possible on Sunday There is also a chance for Les Suetes winds in Cape Breton Island late on Sunday, which may or may not reach warning levels. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and blowing snow today. Snow is expected to begin early this morning as a low pressure system approaches. Snow will then become heavy at times this morning into this afternoon. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm are expected by the time the snow tapers to flurries early Sunday morning. Easterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will cause widespread blowing snow today making travel difficult across the area. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T02:04:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T10:05:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2769811849.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High Storm Surge levels and large waves are expected to impact the coast. Locations: north facing shorelines from Notre Dame Bay to Ferryland. Maximum water levels: significantly exceeding high astronomical tide. Maximum wave heights: 9 to 12 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Time span: continuing until early this afternoon. Next High tide: early this afternoon. Remarks: Higher than normal water levels along the east and northeast coasts due to 60 to 80 cm of storm surge combined with 9 to 12 m waves are expected to persist until the tides begin to subside early this afternoon. Flooding and damage to coastal infrastructure are possible, especially in locations exposed to the north. ### High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-18T22:59:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T08:34:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1983063508.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Location: northwestern New Brunswick Coldest windchills: near minus 35. Time span: this morning. Remarks: A very cold airmass combined with light to moderate winds will give wind chill values near minus 35 this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-18T15:37:48-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong northwesterly flow developing over southern Kivalliq today will bring widespread blowing snow to the region. Winds gusting into the 70-80 km/h range will develop over the Baker Lake area Saturday morning and then spread southeastwards into the coastal communities Saturday afternoon and evening. Ground blizzard conditions will accompany the winds with visibilities reduced to 400 metres or less in blowing snow. These conditions will likely persist into Sunday with improvement occurring Sunday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T01:52:46-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Locations: Burin Peninsula. Time span: this morning. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strong northwesterly winds this morning to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve later this morning as the winds gradually diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong Pacific storm arrives tonight with a mix of wintery weather including snow, freezing rain, and blowing snow. The storm will arrive tonight with snow beginning this evening across East and Central Vancouver Island. Total snowfall of 10 to 20 cm is expected by Saturday morning. However, local 5 to 10 cm are expected near sea level. Strong winds will also accompany the storm. As a result blowing snow is expected overnight tonight and early Saturday morning. As warmer air associated with storm penetrates the region, the snow will likely transition to freezing rain over central Vancouver Island overnight tonight. A complete change over to rain is expected by Saturday morning for all regions. Timing this transition from snow to freezing rain is always challenging in these situations. There is a chance that this transition could be delayed resulting in higher snowfall amounts. Stay tuned to the latest Environment and Climate Change Canada for all the latest warnings and forecasts. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-18T16:34:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-18T07:50:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3717287486.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, Inland Vancouver Island

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: near 110 km/h from the northwest. Locations: Exposed coastal areas from Cartwright to Mary's Harbour. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Strongest winds will likely be in the Black Tickle area. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
